title: Wheels in motion to help raise awareness of regenerative farming
bodyText:
This week, farmer Brendan Guinan will be taking his bike out for a spin around the roads near the Slieve Bloom mountains close to his Fiorbhia Farm in Portlaoise.

He is preparing for a mammoth cross-country cycle next month to promote regenerative farming. Brendan himself is Ireland's first biological agroforest farmer.

This is the second time he's done this trek, having cycled 1,200km from Malin to Mizen Head last year for the same cause. His team of five cyclists visited 10 different farms along the way, to showcase the growth of regenerative farming around the country.

"We highlighted each farm that we went to, showing the work that they were doing," says Brendan. The aim was to bring farmers together and show the viability of regenerative farming.

Over seven days, Brendan organised 10 different events - where each farmer cooked their own produce - and sold tickets to the general public.

"They were like little mini weddings. Good craic, great fun and lots of networking," he says. "It showed that you can produce food without degrading the soil and harming the environment. It really highlighted that farming can be a solution to a lot of problems."

The endeavour was so popular that the group are doing it again this year.

From September 8, they plan to cycle the east coast from the Giant's Causeway to Waterford, highlighting similar farms.

Brendan is a graduate of the MSc in AgInnovation (Agricultural Innovation & Entrepreneurship) at the University of Galway, which he completed in 2023. He credits the course with opening his mind to new ways of solving problems and says it gave him the tools to undertake such endeavours as this long-distance cycle. It also inspired him to work with others.

"It taught me you can't do everything on your own. You need a team around you."

The course was designed by Professor John Breslin, author of Old Ireland in Colour and founder of Galway startup accelerator PorterShed. John has a passion for entrepreneurship and innovation, and saw a gap in rural Ireland.

"He saw that Ireland needed to be helped. And basically it starts with the farmer in the field," says Martina O'Grady. A farmer's daughter from Roscommon, Martina did the course herself four years ago and now teaches on the programme.

The master's aims to foster entrepreneurship in rural Ireland and addresses the challenges faced by farmers in the modern era.

"If you keep doing what you've always done, you're always going to get the same result. You have to be the change yourself. We can give them the confidence to pivot on their farms. Essentially, we need to give farmers courage," says Martina.

"Encouraging them to look at agriculture in a difa ferentw y, and changing the way we do it so that it can survive - that's really what the programme is about."

Martina is keen to stress that "you don't necessarily need any great qualifications coming into the course. It's the passion we're after - if you can show us that there's something that you want to do for rural Ireland to help farmers through innovation, we really want you to succeed."

The Level 9 master's has been running for seven years, with 30-35 participants each year. The course is designed to fit into busy schedules with one two-hour Zoom class per week in the evening and 10 in-person Saturdays at the university over one year.

Prospective students wary about going back to college can take heart from the course diversity, with ages ranging from 22 to 70 years old. As well as farmers, previous course participants have varied backgrounds including a veterinary nurse, a solicitor, a wine shop owner, and tech experts looking to reshape agriculture through technology. A broad range of business ideas that have sprung forth from the course include wool promotion, beekeeping, willow coffin-making and a nature-walk company.

At the end of the course, Martina says that "people felt they had come on this journey with each other, even though they had only met 10 times".

For Brendan, the course has given him the structure and confidence to diversify his farming business. He now cooks at Electric Picnic, has spoken at the Web Summit and gives tours at his farm.

The course offers 90pc funding by Springboard for those in employment, and is 100pc funded for job seekers. The course is still open for applications and the closing date has been extended until August 13. Martina urges people to apply, regardless of circumstances.

"We have farmers saying, 'I'm going to have calving or lambing season in the middle of March; I won't be able to make that Saturday.' I say, 'You're going to find a way between now and then.'" If you want to get those wheels turning and embark on your own AgInnovate adventure, apply on: www.universityofgalway.ie/courses/taught-postgraduate-courses/aginnovation.html

title: Thousands flee raging wildfires across Turkey
bodyText:
Firefighters battled wildfires across Turkey yesterday amid a searing Mediterranean heatwave, with authorities evacuating more than 3,600 people from settlements in two provinces.

Wildfires in the southern provinces of Mersin and Antalya as well as the central province of Usak were largely brought under control, but blazes in the northwestern province of Bursa and the northern province of Karabük were still burning, minister for agriculture and forestry Ibrahim Yumakli told reporters.

A wildfire broke out in a forested area between the Gürsu and Kestel districts of Bursa, home to much of Turkey s auto industry, on Saturday. Part of a highway connecting Istanbul with the western city of Izmir was briefly closed on Saturday night due to the fire.

Huge flames engulfed trees in areas close to homes in Bursa as smoke covered the sky over the city, footage showed.

Some 1,765 people in Bursa s Kestel district were evacuated, Mr Yumakli said, adding that 2,000 firefighters were struggling to battle the wildfire in the area with the help of six firefighting planes and four helicopters.

In the northern province of Karabuk, where a large wildfire has been burning for five days, 1,839 people in 19 villages were evacuated, Mr Yumakli said. Three planes and 16 helicopters are tackling the blazes in the area amid difficult conditions, he added.

We are going through risky times. This does not seem likely to end in two or three days, Mr Yumakli added, referring to the heatwave.

Temperatures in several regions in Turkey were forecast to reach over 40 degrees yesterday, six to 12 degrees above seasonal norms, Turkey s meteorological service said, as thermometers hit 50 degrees in the country s southeast on Saturday for the first time in recorded history.

Firefighters were also battling wildfires across Greece and the Western Balkans on Saturday as the south of Europe sweltered under the third heatwave of the summer, with some villages and settlements also being evacuated in Greece and Albania.

Explosions heard

Explosions could be heard as huge clouds of smoke covered Drosopigi village 25km north of Athens, where factories with flammable material are located. Helicopters dropped water and 145 firefighters battled the flames, assisted by 44 vehicles, seven helicopters and 10 aircraft.

Two houses caught fire while residents of the nearby village of Krioneri were instructed by authorities to leave towards Athens. Five people were taken to hospitals over burns and smoke inhalation.

Temperatures in Greece were forecast to reach up to 44 degrees on Saturday, the Greek weather service said.

In the last 24 hours alone, 52 agroforestry fires broke out, 44 of which were dealt with immediately, in their initial stage, said Vassilios Vathrakogiannis, a spokesman for the fire brigade.

In neighbouring Albania, 26 fires broke out throughout the country on Saturday, following a large fire near the southern Albanian town of Delvina on Friday which injured three people and forced the evacuation of about 2,000 residents.

On the Greek island of Evia, 128 firefighters and 29 vehicles were deployed to put out fires, assisted by six aircraft and seven helicopters, but strong winds hampered their efforts. Residents of the island s Triada area were evacuated. Reuters

title: Centra sponsors tree planting in Ballymagorry
bodyText: CENTRA Ballymagorry is helping to enhance biodiversity and create habitat for wildlife by sponsoring the planting of 250 native hedgerow trees and shrubs in a nearby farm. William and Ashton McKean, who own a small farm in the area, have received the trees including birch, oak, hawthorn, rowan, hazel, and crab apple, through a partnership between the convenience retail brands SuperValu and Centra - part of Musgrave NI - and Trees on the Land, a not-for-profit project from the Green Economy Foundation. The project which launched in 2022, saw 15,000 native trees planted across 50 locations across Northern Ireland in three years, while this year a further 5,000 have been planted in another 20 locations. Colleagues from SuperValu and Centra stores across Northern Ireland have also supported the initiative by pulling on their wellies and visiting many of the tree planting locations. Tree recipient Ashton said: "I would like to thank Centra and Trees on the Land for supporting this project. "There were many conifer trees nearby which blew down due to old age, so these trees will enable us to create hedgerows which will create a new natural habitat for wildlife, shelterbelts for livestock and many more environmental benefits." Paul Kayne, manager of Centra Ballymagorry, visited the site and added: "Centra is committed to supporting local communities and we're delighted that through this project, we can enable more tree coverage at this local farm. "Agroforestry can help make farms more resilient to climate change, with trees helping to prevent flooding, increasing biodiversity and making soils more stable, and we look forward to hearing how the trees mature over the years."

title: 'It feels very satisfying to walk through your own forest'
bodyText:
When I met Julius Brummelman in the woods of Slieve Aughty, Co Galway, he grasped my hand with an iron grip. I knew then that he was a man who was used to hard work.

With his cousin Dylan van Leeuwen, Brummelman built a medieval roundhouse in a beautiful woodland setting in Co Galway during the Covid pandemic.

Surrounded by oak trees and bluebells and next to a bubbling stream, it looks exactly like the sort of place an ancient Irish family might have chosen to settle in.

Brummelman was born in the Netherlands but has lived in Ireland for many years, having followed his aunt and his cousins here. I was three years old when my parents moved to a house within a woodland in Friesland in the north of the Netherlands, he says.

As a child, I was out in the woods every day. This gave me a strong connection with nature, and later combined with the environmental interests that my parents gave me.

Brummelman has been interested in bushcraft since he was a child. He has taken on a range of challenges, living in the woodlands with only basic tools such as a knife and an axe.

I watch him lighting a campfire with just a flint to ignite the kindling that he has collected in the woods. He has also become a self-taught film-maker and his YouTube channel, Smooth Gefixt, has an international audience.

Over the years I have tried to teach myself a variety of woodworking skills, he says.

Wood is such a beautiful and easy material to work with. Trees are so useful for everything from making fires to building houses. I am not against cutting trees at all but we should try to do it in a sustainable, balanced way.

In his practical approach to life, Brummelman says he is always happy to use firewood to heat his house. If demand was higher for timber, he believes that could be a driver for creating more forest cover.

With his family, Brummelman has recently bought an area of woodland near Lough Rainey, Co Clare. This is a conventional conifer plantation, but it is beside an ancient woodland with mostly native tree species.

I saw this as an ideal place to start a conversion from a monoculture plantation to a more mixed woodland, he says.

He will do this conversion in gradual stages, first thinning out the spruce trees and planting native trees in their place.

The existing conifers will provide cover for the native trees to mature and eventually replace them. With this type of continuous cover forestry, both economic and biodiversity values of the forest grow hand in hand.

Brummelman s late father was a vet and he grew up visiting many farms with him.

In Ireland I have been talking to many farmers about woodland, he says. I want to encourage farmers to incorporate trees into their farming enterprises.

Because we don t really have a forest culture any more, most farmers don t think of trees as a useful part of their farming. However, with continuous-cover forestry, the focus can be on individual trees.

Farmers could go into a forest, manage it carefully and add value to individual trees. In that way they would connect more to their woodland. It feels very satisfying to walk through your own forest which is maturing around you.

At the Slieve Aughty Centre, he has been planting an agroforestry plot with a variety of native and non-native trees such as sweet chestnut.

He has a few favourite tree species. He planted a lime tree in memory of his father, who clearly had a big influence on his son s life.

I like eating lime leaves as a salad, he says. For forest development in Ireland, I think oak is the most interesting as it can grow rapidly in good soils with very specific management.

Although he is passionate about trees, he is also a practical person who knows the benefits that trees and woodland offer.

He is very familiar with a variety of European woodlands as he studied Forest and Nature Conservation at Wageningen University in the Netherlands.

Now Brummelman has qualified as a registered forester and is training in the methods of continuous-cover forestry. Learning new skills and methods keeps him fresh and inspires him to achieve more in reforesting Ireland.

Richard Nairn is an ecologist and author

title: Agroforestry grants are up for grabs
bodyText:
The Agricultural Consultants Association (ACA) highlighted the many benefits of agroforestry on Irish farms, with attractive grants available to those considering planting.

According to the ACA, the benefits include more sustainable farming, improved animal welfare, increased biodiversity, climate change mitigation, water protection, renewable energy, timber and soil amelioration.

There are 11 different forest types that can be planted by farmers under the new Forestry Programme.

Agroforestry is forest type 8 (FT8) and allows for the creation of silvopastoral systems (trees and grass), silvoarable systems (trees and crops), and forest gardening systems (small-scale food forest pilot).

The grant/ha (excluding fencing) for silvopastoral, silvoarable and forest gardening are (EURO)8,555, (EURO)6,000, and (EURO)6,000 respectively.

Suitable site type characteristics include free draining mineral soils, elevations below 200 metres, no requirement for additional drainage, no requirement for herbicides and fertilisers, and sheltered areas.

Accepted tree species include oak, sycamore, cherry, alder, walnut and red oak. Other species can be considered. It is acceptable to have between 15pc-40pc fruit and other species depending on the system.

title: Teagasc sees growing interest in native forests by landowners
bodyText:
Interest in native forests was strong in recent clinics, said Teagasc forestry specialist Frances McHugh during a recent Environment Edge podcast.

"That certainly has seen an increase in recent years. Incorporated into that is the 'Forest for Water'. That would be a native forest beside water, and there's a little extra incentive there.

"Another popular one then would be agroforestry, which is quite a different forest. It's relatively new, and a lot of people love the idea of that kind of intimate combination of trees, and being allowed or being facilitated to farm as well, on the same piece of ground. Instead of planting around 2,500 trees per hectare, you're maybe planting around 400 trees per hectare. Because of that, you can protect those trees individually and allow either grass to grow, or there's actually a silvoarable scheme where you can put an arable crop in there. That has become a lot more popular, and there's an agroforestry forum now, an organisation that is working hard to get people that are interested in agroforestry together to compare their successes.

"It certainly ties in, agroforestry in particular, with the organics scheme, where one can still claim the organic payment on agroforestry land, so essentially you may be getting your BISS payment, your agroforestry premium, and also the organic payment as well. That's a really positive broadincentive there, and a real example of how different schemes can work together," Frances said.

"Then, of course, not forgetting the high forest, the mixed commercial forest, which we certainly need as well. We need timber to feed into our sawmilling industry and to capture carbon. There are fast-growing conifers, they're absolutely amazing at grabbing carbon out of the atmosphere, and they do that really, really well. If we store timber in buildings, that's a really positive thing for the environment," Frances said.

There has to be 20% broad-incentive leaf in predominantly conifer forest. There are currently 12 different National Forestry Programme schemes available.

Anyone over 18, with a Personal Public Service (PPS) number, can apply for a grant under the National Forestry Programme, as can a company. The applicant needs to either own, lease or be in joint management of the piece of ground proposed for forestry or agroforestry, said Frances. "You have to be able to demonstrate to the Department that you have the right to make a decision on this pretty major change of land use. You don't have to be a farmer per se.

"There is an incentive there for farmers. The premium is the same rate for everybody, but it's 20 years for farmers and 15 years for non-farmers," she said.

A farmer is defined in this instance as an approved participant in the Basic Income Support for Sustainability (BISS) scheme in the year of application, who has also participated in the previous four years. "It shows that you've been an established farmer for that time," Frances said.

If the applicant is a new entrant to farming, and can establish that fact, allowances can be made.

"There is a licencing process in relation to getting approval for a forest. That's something that a landowner undertakes with a registered forester. There is a requirement to engage a forester that has been registered with the Department, to come out to chat to them, work through what might suit the land, what sort of environmental issues may need to be taken into account, and to plan that forest accordingly.

"That application goes into the Department of Agriculture. If it needs to be referred to outside bodies, that happens, maybe to Fisheries or Archaeology, or different processes like that. That's done within the Department. The applicant doesn't have to go running with a piece of paper to those bodies", Frances explained.

A period will elapse before the licence is issued. "That system has improved over the years," she said.

"To give you an idea of the grant to cover the cost of planting and fencing and everything really to be done on the site, the grant would be 6,744 per hectare. That's money to spend over a four-year period, to get those trees planted, protected and up and running, and established.

title: In brief
bodyText:
Concern over CAP budget changes

Proposed changes to how EU funding will be allocated to agriculture have caused deep concern.

Agricultural ministers across the EU, and now the IFA (Irish Farmers' Association), have said the changes, which include the proposed "merger" of the two existing pillars of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), would be damaging for the sector.

IFA president Francie Gorman recently held a meeting in Brussels with Christiane Canenbley, director at DG Budget, the EU department responsible for the multi annual framework (MFF), which governs how the EU budget is allocated.

The final MFF proposals, once published by the European Commission, will then go before the European Parliament and then the EU Council of heads of state before being finalised, which is a process that could likely take up to 18 months or more.

"It's absolutely critical that both the Taoiseach and the minister for agriculture stand up for Irish farmers in the upcoming negotiations on both the MFF and CAP," said Mr Gorman.

"We cannot allow Irish farmers to be the fall guys for a flawed approach to EU budgeting."

1.5m to fund forestry promotion

A total of 48 projects will benefit from the 1.53m pledged following the Forestry Promotion Project open call.

The announcement was made by Martin Heydon, the minister for agriculture, and Michael Healy-Rae, minister of state.

The projects selected are said to promote many aspects of forestry in a variety of ways. These include support for a forestry village at the national ploughing championships, promotion of agroforestry, and continuous cover forestry, forestry as a career option, a year-long promotional campaign, a continuous professional development model on the use of timber in construction, exploring barriers to women's participation in forestry, and forest and timber certification.

At the announcement, Mr Healy-Rae said: "Peer-led projects promoting the mutual benefits of forestry to landowners and farmers, as well as the sharing of information and good practice, will be of immense benefit in achieving our sustainable forestry targets."

title: Heydon: Forestry on peat is complex and must be science-led
bodyText:
Some soils currently excluded from Ireland's forestry planting will contribute positively if planted, said agriculture minister Martin Heydon last week.

He revealed that forestry on peat is being investigated in a 2.7m research programme, entitled "PeatFor - Management of peatland forests for climate, biodiversity, and water quality". It is a four-year project, but there may be preliminary results within two years.

Responding to Dáil questions, the minister said: "The subject of planting forests on peat soils is not black and white. Forests planted on peat soils can contribute to climate, biodiversity, and timber production."

The subject has been controversial since Michael Healy-Rae, minister of state with responsibility for forestry, said in April that Ireland will not have enough timber if forest planting is restricted to shallower peat soils, less than 30cm deep.

Green Party leader Roderic O'Gorman hit back, saying planting on peatlands would be "environmental madness".

Minister Heydon said last week, "I am not in favour of planting on deep peat sites, where there is a net carbon emission, or planting important peat habitats, blanket bogs, raised bogs, and other important habitats on peat soils. These will remain unplanted".

He confirmed that the EU state aid approval for Ireland's forestry programme prohibits planting on deep peat soils.

"On the other hand, it permits planting of commercial forest and native woodlands on shallower peat soils, less than 30cm deep, and some midland fen peats planted with native woodlands".

Minister Heydon said any changes to forestry programmes must be informed by science.

"Growing forests on peat, and the consequences in relation to carbon, is complex. All trees, as they grow, store an increasing amount of carbon, but peat that is drained emits carbon. There has been a lot of research into this area, but more needs to be done," he said.

"In relation to any future forestry programmes, these will have to be agreed with the EU Commission, and it will be important that whatever we propose as part of that programme, we will be able to back it up with science and common sense".

In April, minister of state Healy-Rae said farmers want to plant peatland.

"Farmers do not want to plant their green ground, because they have worked so hard to get the bit they have. They broke their backs and bones to make the land green, and they do not want to plant trees on it, but instead use it for grazing," he said.

He said things have not been as bad with regard to planting since 1946.

He revealed he hopes to improve the agroforestry scheme. "To be blunt, I do not agree with the terms of the scheme at present. They are not good enough.

"The first bit of advice I would give to a farmer who wants to plant agroforestry at the moment is to wait until we improve the scheme".

He also revealed there will be a reconstitution scheme. Landowners can take out the 25,000 hectares damaged by Storm Eowyn and can retrospectively apply for the reconstitution scheme.

"I just hope we will be able to put together the money to make it strong enough to take the harm out of having to replant".

He said some of the damaged timber might not be heavy enough, resulting in a smaller than expected payment from sawmills, and landowners would not want to overspend on replanting to get back to where they started.

He also revealed an ambition that every privately owned forest in Ireland will be certified.

"Certifying a forest will give people an interest in their forest again. I am not looking to put an imposition of money on them. My aim is that the department will be paying for it".

Minister of state Healy-Rae said every farmer in the country, whether they have forestry or not, should be entitled to carbon credits.

"In my infinite wisdom, many years ago, I automatically assumed that carbon credits were going to be a big thing of the future. I thought we would own them, could trade them, and that they would be a valuable commodity. Unfortunately, we have not got there yet. It is something we all aspire to," he said.

title: Why you should consider agroforestry
bodyText:
The new Forestry Programme 2023-2027 has thrown up some exciting options for farmers to create an aesthetically interesting and financially rewarding feature on their farms. The financial incentives of afforestation have been substantially improved. The forest premium for farmers has been extended to 20 years and the rate of payment has increased to (EURO)863/ha ((EURO)349/ac) for mixed conifers and up to (EURO)1,142/ha ((EURO)462/ac) for certain forest types.

These changes should encourage more planting. Given the ever-increasing value of timber, forestry is among the best investments any farmer could consider.

However, the obligation to re-plant with no supports after clear-fell is a major disincentive. This issue badly needs to be addressed if planting targets - and indeed carbon emission targets - are to be met.

I know many farmers who are reluctant to go down the afforestation route because they view the obligation to replant as something of a poisoned chalice for those that will come after them.

Despite the financial benefit from clear-felling - generally (EURO)25,000-28,000/ha - the cost of re-planting at (EURO)3,500/ha, coupled with no financial return from the replanted forest for many years into the future, does not make for a very attractive inheritance.

However, the income tax-free status of timber sales, and the inheritance tax benefits of forestry are significant factors to be borne in mind.

Agroforestry A booklet titled Agroforestry with Organics that was recently published by the Agricultural Consultants Association (ACA) recently dropped through my virtual letterbox. I would never have associated organics with forestry.

Agroforestry is a combination of trees and grassland or crops on the same piece of land, which enables more sustainable farming, improved animal welfare, increased biodiversity, mitigation of the effects of climate change, water protection, production of renewable energy, localised shelter and production of quality timber.

The booklet emphasises the strong compatibility between the Organic Farming Scheme (OFS) and forestry. OFS parcels can be converted to forestry during the OFS contract without penalty.

The agroforestry scheme is one of the few schemes to seamlessly integrate with the OFS.

The use of trees in an organic system has been seen to be extremely beneficial on many farms throughout Ireland. A more diverse range of habitats improves biodiversity in local and larger ecosystems.

Land declared as agroforestry can be eligible for agroforestry grants and premiums, BISS, CRISS and Organic Payments at the dry stock rate on the same land parcel.

The agroforestry option is now also of real interest to owners of ash dieback-infected plantations - you can convert from dead and dying ash to agroforestry. The area could then be allowable for nitrogen and phosphorus and grassland stocking rate calculations for farmers not in derogation.

The recent announcement of (EURO)5,000/ha available to owners of infected plantations who clear and replant the area under a climate action performance payment is a significant step in the right direction for forestry.

Combining this with the agroforestry option on the replanting should be of real interest to many owners.

Options An agroforestry plot will comprise rows of trees in a grass or tillage field. There are different options within the scheme such as the silvo-pastoral option for drystock farmers and the silvo-arable option for tillage farmers.

There is also a forest gardening option, where fruit and nut trees can occupy up to 40pc of the species planted. This may be of interest to free-range organic poultry producers. Agroforestry payments There is an initial establishment grant of (EURO)8,555/ha for the silvo-pastoral system or (EURO)6,000/ha for the silvo-arable and forest gardening options.

There is an annual premium payable for 10 years that amounts to (EURO)975 for the silvo-pastoral option and (EURO)825 for the other options. These payments are income tax free.

Table 1 sets out an example of a typical farm attracting BISS, CRISS and Eco-Scheme payment of (EURO)250/ha along with the Agroforestry and Organics Farming Scheme payment. Organics Don't forget, farmers can get very attractive payments under the Organic Farming Scheme. In addition to the payment rates as set out in Table 2, there is an administration payment in year one of (EURO)2,000 and an annual payment of (EURO)1,400 thereafter.

For example, a drystock farmer owning 50ha will receive a total annual payment when fully converted of (EURO)14,400.

Further information Contact the Agricultural Consultants Association head office at 051 645705 or at www.aca.ie Martin O'Sullivan is the author of the ACA Farmers' Handbook and is a farm succession consultant with IFAC; www.ifac.ie

title: How this Mayo couple make a living from a 7ac farm by doing something different
bodyText:
On just 7ac in Co Mayo, Aoife and Joe Reilly are proving that small-scale farming can be both sustainable and profitable, if you're willing to do things differently.

From their certified organic farm, Glasraí Organic, in Hollymount near Claremorris, the husband and wife grow over 60 different crops - from leafy greens and root vegetables to herbs, fruit, potatoes and mushrooms, with the help of a year-round team of 10 mostly part-time employees.

They have five commercial-scale polytunnels, which they built themselves from second-hand mushroom houses.

They also keep free-range hens for eggs and recently established a small Angus herd, selling beef directly in boxes. Five years ago, they purchased a separate 20ac block of land, where 7ac is now going into agroforestry and 13ac of old woodland is being grazed by their cattle to encourage regeneration.

The 7ac fruit-and-vegetable enterprise is based on land Joe got from his father and grew from an original 3ac. He trained as a carpenter and worked in Australia for several years before returning home during the economic downturn, when he began growing vegetables for his own use.

Aoife and Joe met through an organic horticulture course and went on to establish Glasraí Organic Farm in 2016.

"We decided to grow our own produce because, first of all, we were drawn to the lifestyle. We wanted to make a living off the land while looking after it at the same time. We feel like we are giving something back to the land by looking after soil health and fertility, and it's giving us produce," Aoife explains.

"For Joe, it was the actual vegetables themselves. Ask anyone who has grown their own food and they will swear it tastes so much better. Having kids grow up on a farm is important to us as parents. We value working outside and good food."

Direct selling their veggie-box scheme, farmers' markets two days a day in Westport and Castlebar and their online shop accounts for 80pc of their sales.

The remaining 20pc of business involves supplying other growers, restaurants, local shops and a supermarket in Westport.

About 70pc of what they sell comes directly from their farm. "We buy fruit from other organic farms in Ireland, but there's still very little organic fruit in Ireland, so we often import from Europe. There are certain things, like sweet potatoes, that people are used to, that we can't grow here."

Aoife says salad leaves, strawberries and potatoes are the three most popular items, while some people come to the farmers' markets for their hen eggs alone.

"I grew up on packet eggs, and ever since we got our own hens, I haven't tried shop-bought eggs."

The family eats what they produce, from vegetables to eggs and beef.

"I'm really happy that our kids are eating our own beef and I know where it's coming from. I've become more interested in and conscious about food over the years."

She says their customers are people who care about where their food comes from, whether they're passionate about organics, climate, local economies or simply good taste.

She says sales have been "consistent" in recent years, and they try to keep prices consistent year-round, for simplicity.

"For some people, food isn't always high on the priority list when you can buy vegetables cheaply. All we can do is to be there and represent the true cost of producing the food.

"And that's what I'd like to stand for: the real cost of food, and not subsidising food and not using low-cost strategies to undermine the value or the cost of food."

She says pricing is a balancing act. "You must keep an eye on the market and factor in your production costs too. I like to think that people pay what they feel is reasonable to them, and it feels fair to us. I don't think of us charging a premium. A bunch of carrots from us costs (EURO)3."

The Reillys are members of the Organic Trust and went into organics for transparency.

"We can see value in being organic. It gives confidence to consumers that these are the standards our produce has been grown within," she says.

Aoife adds that being certified organic involves more paperwork, more soil testing and other ways, such as crop rotations, netting and minimal tillage, to boost soil health.

When the couple first started, the site was a blank canvas, but the land itself was of good quality.

"It pays to have good land to start off with, rather than having to build it up over the years, because it takes so long."

Over the years, they have fenced the land, thickened hedgerows to create wildlife corridors, and planted thousands of native trees as hedgerows and shelterbelts to protect their polytunnels.

They have dug three ponds to attract frogs and have worked on naturally building up soil fertility slowly using seaweed and green manures. Aoife says they wouldn't drive machinery on their land "without exercising caution".

They do not use pesticides, herbicides or chemical fertilisers. "We learned how to grow vegetables without chemicals, so it was never a thing of how to replace them."

Most of the work on the farm, including harvesting and weeding, is done by hand, with some tractor-drawn implements used for cultivation, but labour remains largely manual.

"When you're doing three-quarters of an acre of carrots, it doesn't come high on the priority list to purchase a carrot harvester.

"There are a lot of times you wouldn't be able to harvest carrots with a machine because of the weather. We leave most things in the field and dig as needed. This ensures we keep everyone employed over the winter, so we don't have to hire seasonally.

"Because we're not entirely dependent on machinery, we're resilient when we face weather challenges. At the same time, you're looking for a break in the weather to get jobs, such as weeding, done."

The end of the week is the busiest time for the team, from harvesting to farmers' markets, wholesalers and veggie boxes. Two days a week, they distribute to markets and do deliveries.

Aoife says they started the business "the same way a lot of people do, with minimal resources, without massive amounts of capital to invest".

"As we grew over the years, we built up to a place where things have become more sustainable, buying second-hand machinery from growers.

"If there's a job that can be done easier with a machine, we'd like to be able to invest, not to replace people, but rather to make the job easier for employees.

"We don't have a massive budget to buy the exact machines that we often want, but we're still being opportunistic."

Aoife says it is viable to make a living from a 7ac farm, but she says earning a living from a small business can be difficult because "things are changing from year to year, making it hard to keep up".

"We have to be able to keep pace with wages. We value our employees, and we want people to get a fair wage for their labour. The work can be quite intense. A lot of our staff would be harvesting, attending markets, and someone is doing deliveries. But it's not a lonely job - we work together.

"We're fortunate to have a brilliant team that helps us make it work. Some people have been with us for years."

title: Growing interest in new agroforestry programme
bodyText:
There is a lot of interest in the agroforesty part of the new 2023-2027 Forestry Programme, said Seppi Hona during a recent episode of the Teagasc Signpost podcasts.

"If s gaining a lot of momentum across Europe and in the UK", said Mr Hona, a Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine forestry inspector.

Grants for agroforesty facilitate landowners in planting land with trees and continuing to produce food through agriculture.

"This is basically where you can plant trees with wide spacing and continue a level of farming between and under the trees," Seppi explained.

Silvopastoral agroforestry combines the grazing by sheep or young cattle with trees. Animals can be grazed during the spring and summer for the first six to eight years (the grazing period depends on the rate of tree growth). Thereafter, when tree shelters are replaced with plastic mesh, larger animals may be introduced. Silage or hay production is permitted, using appropriate machinery so that the trees are not inadvertently damaged.

Agroforestry grants increased significantly in the new Forestry Programme. The planting grant is 8,555/ha, and an annual premium of 6975 is payable for ten years. The rates are the same for farmers and non-farmers.

Silvoarable agroforestry combines growing cereals, or fruit and vegetables, with trees. Fruit and nut trees can account for 20% of the species planted. A planting grant of 6,000, and a premium of 829 per year for 10 years, are payable.

The DAFM says silvoarable agroforestry should initially be set up on a pilot basis, with a maximum of 30ha per year for four projects of up to 7.5ha each.

The third and final agroforestry category is forest gardening. The objective is to provide robust, small-scale forests that provide a source of organic forest food (for poultry, for example). Fruit and nut trees can account for up to 40% of the species planted.

Forest gardening applications are limited to one hectare per landowner. A grant of 6,000 is available, as well as a premium of 829 per year, for ten years, with no difference in rates between farmers and non-farmers.

A fencing grant is also available, to ensure that newly established trees are fully protected from browsing animals.

The DAFM says there is a one-hectare limit per landowner, with a national ceiling of 6ha annually.

To be eligible for payments, any agroforestry plot must be at least 0.5ha; at least 20m wide (measured from tree to tree). The required stocking rate is at least 400 trees per ha at equal planting spacing, with up to 10m between rows, and at least three metres between trees in a row. All trees must have two stakes and a shelter to protect them from browsing, rubbing, or fraying. Acceptable tree species include oak, sycamore and cherry.

Other species (including conifers) may be considered on a site-by-site basis. An afforestation licence will be needed to participate in agroforesty. Farmers can approach a registered forester to assess the site and to assist in the application. Registered foresters are professional foresters, working either as consultant foresters or employed by forestry companies. They are registered with the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine (DAFM) and authorised to submit forestry grant scheme applications.

"All applications undergo a rigorous environment assessment procedure," Seppi Hona explained. If the application is successful and if one decides to go ahead, then the same registered forester will continue to be involved, by co-ordinating some or all of the work. Farmers can also seek advice from Teagasc forestry advisors, who are available to support landowners and to provide free, independent and objective advice on all forestryrelated issues.

The Native Tree Area (NTA) scheme supports the creation of small native forests up to one hectare. NTA 1 is for the creation of small native forests on farmed land, while NTA 2 is for the creation of small native forests for water protection. For both, a total planting grant of 6,744 is available. A premium of 2,206 is payable for 10 years for NTA 1, the premium is 2,284 for NTA 2.

An afforestation licence is not required. "We're turning these around in four to six weeks," Seppi Hona said.

Both farmers and nonfarmers can apply. "It does require a site visit by a registered forester, and a registered forester has to do your application." Each site is assessed in relation to its topographical location, soil, main habitats, and vegetation.

title: Can we feed the world and save it too?
bodyText:
IMAGINE a future where every field is organic. No synthetic fertilisers, no pesticides, and only nature-based methods guiding how we grow our food. The air is cleaner. Pollinators are thriving. Soil is healthy.

Now imagine a very different scene. Industrial-scale farms using precision technology to push yields to their limits, automated, efficient, and engineered to feed billions from tightly managed plots. The rest of the land? Given back to forests, wetlands, or wildlife.

Which of these futures is better for the planet?

This question sits at the heart of a global dilemma: Should we make all farming organic or focus on intensifying production in specific areas and rewild the rest? It's a trade-off that pits land sparing against land sharing, and the answer isn't as straightforward as many might hope.

Organic everywhere: better for biodiversity, worse for space?

Organic farming has earned its eco-friendly image. It avoids synthetic inputs, supports biodiversity, and often improves soil health. But it also comes with a major challenge: lower yields. On average, organic farms produce less food per hectare than conventional ones - on average 10-25% lower yields, although this varies by farming type and region. Meaning we'd need much more land to grow the same amount of food organically.

Globally, this raises an uncomfortable truth, if we go fully organic, we may have to convert more land to agriculture. Land that might otherwise be forests, peatlands, natural grasslands, for example. That extra land demand could accelerate biodiversity loss, increase greenhouse gas emissions, and threaten the very ecosystems organic farming seeks to protect.

A 2019 study published in the journal Nature Communications, and led by Britain's Cranfield University, found that going fully organic in Britain could increase the carbon footprint of food production by up to 70%, mostly due to land-use change overseas to compensate for lower yields. In other words, what we gain in pesticide reduction, we may lose in deforestation and carbon debt elsewhere.

Land sparing: high-yield farming, but at what cost?

The alternative? Intensify production on the most suitable land using highy-ield methods, synthetic fertilisers, irrigation, and even genetically modified crops, while sparing other land entirely for nature. Known as the land sparing model, this approach banks on efficiency. The idea is simple: grow more on less land, so that we can set aside more of the planet for conservation and rewilding.

In theory, it's sound. Modelling studies suggest that intensifying production on existing farmland could allow for up to 40% of agricultural land to be restored to natural habitats, if done right. But there are huge caveats.

First, intensive farming often depletes soil, pollutes water, and erodes local biodiversity. It's also a major driver of greenhouse gas emissions, especially from livestock and fertiliser use. Without strict environmental regulations, intensification can do more harm than good. Second, land sparing relies on strong policy enforcement. Just because one area produces more doesn't mean another area will automatically be rewilded. Too often, both areas are exploited: intensify here and expand there, chasing economic returns over ecological balance.

A third way? Smarter hybrids

What if the real solution lies between these extremes? Rather than choosing organic everywhere or intensification somewhere, many scientists now advocate for a sustainable intensification approach: combining ecological practices with modern science and technology. Think precision fertiliser use, cover crops, integrated pest management, agroforestry, and drought-resistant crop varieties, which are applied strategically in different contexts.

In some areas, especially in regions with high population density or poor soils, organic or agroecological methods may work best. In others, especially where yields are already high, efficiency gains through innovation may free up land for nature.

This nuanced approach supports land-use triage, where prioritising land for farming, conservation, and multi-use based on local environmental, social, and economic conditions.

Feeding 10 billion people without breaking the planet

By 2050, the world will need to feed nearly 10 billion people. That means producing more food while using less land, water, and carbon. The global food system already accounts for over one-third of greenhouse gas emissions, and agriculture is the leading cause of deforestation and biodiversity decline.

To meet this challenge, we can't rely solely on ideology, whether it's techdriven maximalism or organic purity. Instead, we need evidence-based, regionally adapted food systems that recognise trade-offs for win-wins.

This includes:

(1) shifting diets, especially reducing high-emission foods like beef in favour of more plant-based proteins

(2) cutting food waste, which currently squanders up to 30% of global food production

(3) supporting smallholder farmers, particularly in the less developed countries, where yield gaps are large but often due to lack of access to tools, credit, or knowledge, and not poor practice, and finally

(4) investing in agroecological transitions that don't just mimic nature, but restore its functions in food production.

What can Ireland do?

Ireland, with more than 68% of land used for agriculture, mostly for beef and dairy, is deeply tied to these global debates. Should we expand organic? Intensifly grazing more efficiently? Rewet peatlands and reduce cattle numbers? The answer likely lies in doing all of the above, strategically.

That means, protecting carbon-rich landscapes like peatlands from expansion, and supporting organic and regenerative methods on marginal land, using precision technology and nutrient budgeting on high-output farms, and designing fair transition schemes that support farmers in making evidence-informed choices.

It's not either/or

There is no silver bullet. But the wrong question is 'which system is best?'

A better question is 'how can we design farming systems that meet human needs without destroying the ecosystems that make life possible?'

Sometimes that will mean going organic. Sometimes it will mean going high-tech. But always, it will mean going smarter.

title: Podcasts
bodyText:
HIDE FM 4.3FM; www.thehideproject.com CONVERSATIONS BENEATH THE TREES Apple, Spotify TREES A CROWD Apple, Spotify; treesacrowd.fm

The birds are singing, early blossoms are emerging and while it's not exactly warm, spring is palpably in the air. High time for some nature broadcasting.

Obviously there's no better tonic than being outside in nature itself, breathing in its myriad scents and feeling the wind in your hair while keeping the body moving. But, nonetheless, it's scientifically proven that even looking at images of natural landscapes releases happy hormones. Similarly, the sound of birdsong - whether in real life or recorded - is known to bring down stress levels. So in the absence of a green space right on your doorstep, tune into Hide FM, the latest site-specific project of Fingal multimedia artist Garrett Phelan. It's a 24- hour radio station documenting birdlife around the old Balleally landfill site that between Lusk and Rush is now a burgeoning nature reserve of sorts as it bleeds into the salt marshes, wet meadows and riverine creeks of Rogerstown estuary. From March 24 to April 20, Phelan will whisper observational and conceptual dispatches, each day dedicated to a specific bird and their feeding, migratory and breeding behaviours, while weaving in associated folklore. Catherine Cleary was best known as a journalist until she co-founded Pocket Forests in 2020, a tree-planting social enterprise inspired by the techniques of Akira Miyawaki, the Japanese botanist who pioneered a system of planting native fauna to help support and restore biodiversity in echo of our ancient forests. She's on a mission to spread the good word, which includes Conversation Beneath the Trees. It assembles scientists, farmers, conservationists, foragers and innovators to share experiences of farming with trees. The likes of regenerative farming, agroforestry policies, permaculture and catchment science are all up for lively discussion among those on the front lines of climate change, industrial waste, habit loss and often divisive legislation.

Just as Knepp rewilding guru Isabella Tree's name always inspires delight, there's no better man than actor, environmentalist and Woodland Trust ambassador David Oakes for hosting Trees a Crowd. Here, he has informal chats with fellow artists and enthusiasts (from Chris Packham to our very own Katie Holten), discussing how nature inspires and shapes our lives. Butterflies, boars, bogs, bison and other things not beginning with B are all exuberantly examined and championed.

title: Let's break bread! 15 tasty community-boosting food and drink hubs to visit this summer
bodyText:
Food and drink are powerful tools for building community and forging connections. Coming together with others to grow or source food, to plan a meal, to break bread, to raise a toast: these are some of the most basic human instincts that remind us of how we're stronger and better together.

At a time when the world feels increasingly fractured and polarised, it can be nourishing for both body and soul to seek community and connection through shared food and drink experiences.

Kudos then to the creative entrepreneurs and hospitality professionals who are tapping into this basic human need to connect and find our folk, and harnessing that in positive ways. From grassroots community festivals and social-enterprise markets to co-op-owned breweries and collective fundraisers, here are 15 unique community-focused food and drink hubs and happenings to seek out this summer.

Priory Market

Main Road, Tallaght, Co Dublin

We flagged John Kearns of the Partas social enterprise as 'One to Watch' for 2025. Now his ambitious vision for the indoor food-and-drink Priory Market has taken root and he has opened the doors to Tallaght's new social, cultural and gastronomic destination.

Open 11am to 11pm daily, this multi-faceted hub hosts 16 curated food and drink spaces serving cuisines from Afro-Caribbean and Latin American to Indian and Italian, each small independent business benefiting from the collective model's reduced running costs of rent and rates. There is freshly roasted coffee from Priory Coffee Roasters and the freshest of beer from Priory Brewing's onsite brewery, taproom and tank bar. The project supports 130 local jobs, fosters start-ups and artisans, and brings new life into the old Tallaght village with The Apex theatre and spaces for live gigs, seminars and more. All profits go back into the community through projects like The Edge incubation hub. priorymarket.ie

Féile an Phráta

July 13, Tigh Uí Beag Laoigh, Ballydavid, Co Kerry

Dingle excels at drawing visitors to its town and peninsula through a diverse calendar of festivals. The first weekend in October is a major date for food and drink lovers and producers across Ireland, thanks to the Dingle Food Festival and Blas na hÉireann awards.

Féile an Phráta is different, says organiser Rochie Holohan, and not just because it celebrates the very local potato growers of West Kerry. This celebration of local community, the humble spud and the Irish language brings neighbours together for some old-fashioned craic, banter and bragging as they battle to be crowned Laoch an Phráta (the Potato Champion).

"Unlike most other festivals," Holohan explains, "we're not trying to attract visitors." That said, visitors and their cúpla focal are most welcome to join the fun in Tigh Uí Beag Laoigh (Begley's pub) for the Sunday final of the week-long 'spud-off', conducted across eight local areas to find the tastiest potato. facebook.com/FeileanPhrata

The John Hewitt

Cathedral Quarter, Belfast, Co Antrim

Belfast is blessed with distinctive pubs but this might be its most unusual. John Hewitt was a poet, socialist and Freeman of Belfast who in 1983 established the Belfast Unemployed Resource Centre. They went on in 1999 to open this social-enterprise pub in his name.

Having built a loyal fanbase for its warm hospitality and diverse arts and music programme (depending on when you land, you might join a hushed trad session, live local gig or hopping dance floor), in 2022 the running of the pub was handed over to Boundary Brewing.

They couldn't have picked a better partner. Boundary Brewing is a members-owned, co-operative-run brewery. Established in 2015, the brewery and later its taproom were funded through a series of Community Share Offers. Like the Newtownards Road taproom, the Cathedral Quarter pub offers 16 taps as well as fridges crammed with cans from Boundary Brewing and international friends, plus food from Franky's Lasagneria. boundarybrewing.coop/pages/the-john-hewitt

Cloughjordan Ecovillage

Cloughjordan, Co Tipperary

Community is everything at Cloughjordan Ecovillage, which was dreamt up by environmental sustainability pioneers in the late 1990s. The first residents moved into their eco-homes in 2009, and there are plans for more to come. The ecovillage is also home to Django's Hostel (with private en suite rooms from €45) and Riot Rye bakery and bread school (with excellent one-day courses from beginner to pro levels).

At the heart of the fertile 67-acre site is a members-owned biodynamic and organic community farm. Visitors are very welcome, whether for formal tours, informal workshops in the research, education and development garden that hosts 'Eats and Beats' DJ nights with a multi-course farm-to-fork meal, or any of the many events the village hosts year-round.

In the main village itself, you'll find eclectic reads and proper coffee at Sheelagh na Gig Bookshop, and wholesome fare at Middle Country Cafe. thevillage.ie

One Plate for Palestine

July 22-27, various locations (see Instagram for participating businesses)

There is community to be found in solidarity. If you're feeling helpless about the sorry state of the world, it can bring hope to come together with like-minded souls to raise funds that will make a small but important difference.

One Plate for Palestine is a new campaign raising funds for those people starving in Palestine. Over a week in late July, many Irish restaurants, cafes, bars, food trucks and market stalls will add a special dish or drink to their menu featuring Palestinian ingredients, such as za'atar, sumac, labneh, hummus, dates, olives or olive oil, with all funds raised going to charities working on the ground to bring fresh water and meals to the people of Gaza living in extremely challenging conditions.?

Look out too for The Wine Shed's 'Vino with a View' fundraiser (July 20) at West Cork's Moss & Sand yoga studio for Aclaí Palestine gym in the West Bank. @oneplateforpalestine

Airfield Estate

Dundrum, Dublin 14

A 38-acre working farm where you can watch Jersey cows being milked and Rhode Island Red hens laying eggs, and stroll lush gardens with views of the Dublin Mountains. Bi-weekly farmers' markets, a garden centre and an elegant restaurant serving farm-to-fork breakfasts, brunches and lunches plus pastries, cakes and cookies. An educational kitchen sharing cooking skills and inspiration, and family-friendly events that ramp up in the summer. There are many reasons to visit Airfield Estate - and every visit gives back to the wider community.

As a social enterprise, profits from ticket sales and Overends Kitchen support the estate's educational and research programmes. Airfield welcomes 12,000 educational visitors every year - from pre-school through primary, secondary and third-level to adults with special needs - to learn about the cycle of food from soil to society, and how our food choices can benefit people, planet and pocket. airfield.ie

Hi Spirits 'Wine Down' Summer Series

Row Wines, Coppinger Row, Dublin 2

Ngozi Elobuike?has been busy. The founder of Hi Spirits Wine Club - Dublin's black-led wine and spirits collective, described on her website as a "dynamic platform that intertwines exceptional wine experiences with a celebration of diversity and heritage" - has been collaborating with everyone from Ireland Fashion Week and Ayo's Table (a modern African supper club) in Dublin to Off Piste Apres Ski in the French Alps.

This month, Hi Spirits returns to Row Wines every Sunday afternoon for a summer series of their 'Wine Down' residency: "curated community moments blending DJ sets, chef-driven Afro-Caribbean food and artful wine pairings" for Dublin's "most curious and culture-loving tastemakers".

Wines poured include Episteme Cuvee 2024, a Gamay-based Pet-Nat natural sparkling wine created by Elobuike herself as part of another collaboration, this time as an?MBA candidate in Wine & Spirits at Burgundy School of Business in partnership with Burgundian winemaker Armand Heitz. hispiritswineclub.com

Irish Seed Savers

Capparoe, Scariff, Co Clare

The Irish Seed Savers Association is a national biodiversity treasure, quite literally. Located near the lower shores of Lough Derg, they research and cultivate heritage apple trees and vegetable seeds to preserve them in Ireland's only living public seed bank and field bank. Surplus produce is sold through their onsite and online shops to conserve these varieties and spread them countrywide through private gardens, smallholdings and farms.

The onsite cafe, art gallery and gift shop, plus bookable guided group tours and free self-guided tours of their 20-acre organic gardens, orchards and woodlands, make for an excellent day-trip. Be sure to sample their Irish heritage apple juice, which won a recent Community Food Award?from the Irish Food Writers' Guild and is produced from organically grown apples in their National Collection of Heritage Apples - or catch their 'Taste the Orchards' apple-tasting tours on September 27. irishseedsavers.ie

Polish Fizz @ Phibs!

July 26, Fíon Eile, Phibsborough, Dublin 7

Independent wine stores are more than simple retail spaces: they also offer access to a community who are passionate and knowledgeable about the wines they sell and the dedicated producers who make them.

Since opening their doors this spring, neighbourhood wine shop Fíon Eile's owners, Paul Gartland and Sinéad McCarthy, have collaborated with some of our most interesting wine importers on a series of tastings for local wine lovers.

This month, they team up with Maggie Domaradzka and Maja Ignaczewska behind the dynamic Polish Wine Fest for a celebration of bubbles from above 50 degrees north of the equator. Maggie and Maja never fail to deliver a fun and fascinating event and, over this 90-minute ticketed session (€38.52), you can taste 15 different Polish sparkling wines - from?traditional-method sparklers?(think Polish-style champagne) to vibrant, low-intervention?Pet-Nats. polishwinefest.com, fioneile.ie

Dundalk Food & Drink Society

Dundalk, Co Louth

Food and drink are excellent levellers, and with members ranging from 18 to 90 years old, this Dundalk-based society of local foodies is doing a fine job of fostering intergenerational friendships.

Founder Sarah Jane Carville describes the society as "a community of passionate individuals who celebrate culinary diversity and are dedicated to exploring new flavours, techniques and cuisines".

Attracting 200 members in their first year, their busy calendar of events includes monthly supper clubs with local chefs, 'Taste the Town' food-and-drink pairings hosted in community hubs like Mo Chara brewpub, and 'Meet the Maker' day-trips to local producers.

A visit to Carlingford Oyster Company run by the wonderful Kian Louet-Feisser and family was a recent highlight, as was the first of the summer's bus trips across the Cooley Peninsula, tasting everything from apple tarts to lobster rolls, to be repeated on July 19. @dundalk_food_and_drink_society

Me Auld Flower food market

Scorchio HQ, Greenmount Industrial Estate, Harold's Cross, Dublin 12

From the people behind Dublin's Big Grill festival (August 14-17), which gathers live-fire-obsessed cooks and chefs from around the world for one smoking weekend in Herbert Park, Scorchio HQ is their new year-round headquarters for pop-ups, parties and weekly markets, with Me Auld Flower food market running every Sunday this summer.

Pride of place goes to the Scorchio live-fire grill, complemented by a wine bar and rotating guest vendors from the likes of Teddy's, Xi'an Street Food and Home Dogs.

Accessed through the building of a former film studio, the sun-trap yard (with indoor toilets) has been reconfigured as "a space built for chefs, creators and food lovers, offering a place to cook, connect and celebrate".

Check @scorchiohq each week on Instagram for that week's line-up and opening times. scorchiohq.com, @meauldflowerfestival

Hagstravaganza

August 9, The White Hag Brewery, Ballymote, Co Sligo

Hagstravaganza brings a global line-up of breweries from the US, UK, Italy, France and Ireland to Ballymote for a one-day celebration of bold beers and community buzz.

Now in its 11th year, this is more than a festival, says White Hag Brewery founder Bob Coggins: "It's a reunion. Every year we welcome back friends from the brewing community, who travel across the world to join us, alongside a growing local and national crowd of die-hard beer lovers. It's the kind of event where brewers pour pints, punters turn into pals, and everyone leaves with a new favourite beer... and a few new mates."

More than 80 beers will be poured, amid live music and DJ sets, brewery tours and Beer Garden Olympics, plus cocktails and food trucks serving everything from oysters to roast chicken to burgers. Then it's time to board the train back to Sligo with stories and songs still flowing. thewhitehag.com

Fondita Mestiza

Various locations in Dublin

Fondita Mestiza began as intimate art-inspired suppers and brunches in Andrea Flores and Erick Carrillo's flat. They took inspiration from their native Mexico's fondas: simple eateries serving home-cooked meals on colourful tablecloths in a family-friendly setting. Marrying her cooking skills and his art-criticism background, their flat's walls exhibited the artworks that inspired each meal. Their aim? To build bridges between cultures through food shared and knowledge exchanged.

It has recently morphed into larger pop-ups in public spaces like Temple Bar Galleries. With the help of friend Joatam Guevara, the menus and art installations explore crossover elements of Mexican and Irish culture, such as our street markets and seafood scenes. The Marisqueria Pop-Up (July 26, Hen's Teeth) celebrates Mexico's casual marisqueria seafood restaurants, and will feature live music and curated drinks pairings alongside food and art, followed by an August pop-up featuring Turkish artist Merve Sagit. fonditamestiza.com

Brookfield Farm

Coolbawn, Nenagh, Co Tipperary

Ailbhe Gerrard's regenerative farm produces raw Irish honey, potatoes, rapeseed oil and organic lamb, plus handcrafted candles, beeswax furniture polish and gardener's hand salve. She also welcomes visitors to the farm with beekeeping and candle-making workshops, honey-tasting sessions and farm tours.

Informed by her Master of Science degree in Organic Farming and Environment and Sustainable Development, visitors learn how biodiversity is fostered through native woodlands and wildflower meadows, arable margins, beehives, bird and bat boxes, and wild bird cover.

Brookfield also hosts a two-day Field Exchange Festival (September 5-6). Friday welcomes anyone interested in how creativity impacts farming practices relating to climate and biodiversity, including policymakers, public servants and farmers.

Saturday's family-friendly programme features craft workshops, local Tipperary food and craft stalls, sensory farm walks, agroforestry and dry-stone wall exhibits, specially commissioned artworks and a musical performance from The Company of Trees. brookfield.farm/field-exchange-festival

Cork on a Fork Fest

August 13-17, various locations throughout Cork city

One of the real strengths of the Irish food and drink scene is the people who are driving it. bodyText:
Food and drink are powerful tools for building community and forging connections. Coming together with others to grow or source food, to plan a meal, to break bread, to raise a toast: these are some of the most basic human instincts that remind us of how we're stronger and better together.

At a time when the world feels increasingly fractured and polarised, it can be nourishing for both body and soul to seek community and connection through shared food and drink experiences.

Kudos then to the creative entrepreneurs and hospitality professionals who are tapping into this basic human need to connect and find our folk, and harnessing that in positive ways. From grassroots community festivals and social-enterprise markets to co-op-owned breweries and collective fundraisers, here are 15 unique community-focused food and drink hubs and happenings to seek out this summer.

Priory Market

Main Road, Tallaght, Co Dublin

We flagged John Kearns of the Partas social enterprise as 'One to Watch' for 2025. Now his ambitious vision for the indoor food-and-drink Priory Market has taken root and he has opened the doors to Tallaght's new social, cultural and gastronomic destination.

Open 11am to 11pm daily, this multi-faceted hub hosts 16 curated food and drink spaces serving cuisines from Afro-Caribbean and Latin American to Indian and Italian, each small independent business benefiting from the collective model's reduced running costs of rent and rates. There is freshly roasted coffee from Priory Coffee Roasters and the freshest of beer from Priory Brewing's onsite brewery, taproom and tank bar. The project supports 130 local jobs, fosters start-ups and artisans, and brings new life into the old Tallaght village with The Apex theatre and spaces for live gigs, seminars and more. All profits go back into the community through projects like The Edge incubation hub. priorymarket.ie

Féile an Phráta

July 13, Tigh Uí Beag Laoigh, Ballydavid, Co Kerry

Dingle excels at drawing visitors to its town and peninsula through a diverse calendar of festivals. The first weekend in October is a major date for food and drink lovers and producers across Ireland, thanks to the Dingle Food Festival and Blas na hÉireann awards.

Féile an Phráta is different, says organiser Rochie Holohan, and not just because it celebrates the very local potato growers of West Kerry. This celebration of local community, the humble spud and the Irish language brings neighbours together for some old-fashioned craic, banter and bragging as they battle to be crowned Laoch an Phráta (the Potato Champion).

"Unlike most other festivals," Holohan explains, "we're not trying to attract visitors." That said, visitors and their cúpla focal are most welcome to join the fun in Tigh Uí Beag Laoigh (Begley's pub) for the Sunday final of the week-long 'spud-off', conducted across eight local areas to find the tastiest potato. facebook.com/FeileanPhrata

Cathedral Quarter, Belfast, Co Antrim

Belfast is blessed with distinctive pubs but this might be its most unusual. John Hewitt was a poet, socialist and Freeman of Belfast who in 1983 established the Belfast Unemployed Resource Centre. They went on in 1999 to open this social-enterprise pub in his name.

Having built a loyal fanbase for its warm hospitality and diverse arts and music programme (depending on when you land, you might join a hushed trad session, live local gig or hopping dance floor), in 2022 the running of the pub was handed over to Boundary Brewing.

They couldn't have picked a better partner. Boundary Brewing is a members-owned, co-operative-run brewery. Established in 2015, the brewery and later its taproom were funded through a series of Community Share Offers. Like the Newtownards Road taproom, the Cathedral Quarter pub offers 16 taps as well as fridges crammed with cans from Boundary Brewing and international friends, plus food from Franky's Lasagneria. boundarybrewing.coop/pages/the-john-hewitt

Cloughjordan Ecovillage

Cloughjordan, Co Tipperary

Community is everything at Cloughjordan Ecovillage, which was dreamt up by environmental sustainability pioneers in the late 1990s. The first residents moved into their eco-homes in 2009, and there are plans for more to come. The ecovillage is also home to Django's Hostel (with private en suite rooms from €45) and Riot Rye bakery and bread school (with excellent one-day courses from beginner to pro levels).

At the heart of the fertile 67-acre site is a members-owned biodynamic and organic community farm. Visitors are very welcome, whether for formal tours, informal workshops in the research, education and development garden that hosts 'Eats and Beats' DJ nights with a multi-course farm-to-fork meal, or any of the many events the village hosts year-round.

In the main village itself, you'll find eclectic reads and proper coffee at Sheelagh na Gig Bookshop, and wholesome fare at Middle Country Cafe. thevillage.ie

One Plate for Palestine

July 22-27, various locations (see Instagram for participating businesses)

There is community to be found in solidarity. If you're feeling helpless about the sorry state of the world, it can bring hope to come together with like-minded souls to raise funds that will make a small but important difference.

One Plate for Palestine is a new campaign raising funds for those people starving in Palestine. Over a week in late July, many Irish restaurants, cafes, bars, food trucks and market stalls will add a special dish or drink to their menu featuring Palestinian ingredients, such as za'atar, sumac, labneh, hummus, dates, olives or olive oil, with all funds raised going to charities working on the ground to bring fresh water and meals to the people of Gaza living in extremely challenging conditions.?

Dundrum, Dublin 14

An educational kitchen sharing cooking skills and inspiration, and family-friendly events that ramp up in the summer. Ngozi Elobuike?has been busy. This month, Hi Spirits returns to Row Wines every Sunday afternoon for a summer series of their 'Wine Down' residency: "curated community moments blending DJ sets, chef-driven Afro-Caribbean food and artful wine pairings" for Dublin's "most curious and culture-loving tastemakers".

Wines poured include Episteme Cuvee 2024, a Gamay-based Pet-Nat natural sparkling wine created by Elobuike herself as part of another collaboration, this time as an?MBA candidate in Wine & Spirits at Burgundy School of Business in partnership with Burgundian winemaker Armand Heitz. hispiritswineclub.com

Capparoe, Scariff, Co Clare

The Irish Seed Savers Association is a national biodiversity treasure, quite literally. Located near the lower shores of Lough Derg, they research and cultivate heritage apple trees and vegetable seeds to preserve them in Ireland's only living public seed bank and field bank. The onsite cafe, art gallery and gift shop, plus bookable guided group tours and free self-guided tours of their 20-acre organic gardens, orchards and woodlands, make for an excellent day-trip. Be sure to sample their Irish heritage apple juice, which won a recent Community Food Award?from the Irish Food Writers' Guild and is produced from organically grown apples in their National Collection of Heritage Apples - or catch their 'Taste the Orchards' apple-tasting tours on September 27. irishseedsavers.ie

Polish Fizz @ Phibs!

July 26, Fíon Eile, Phibsborough, Dublin 7

Independent wine stores are more than simple retail spaces: they also offer access to a community who are passionate and knowledgeable about the wines they sell and the dedicated producers who make them.

Since opening their doors this spring, neighbourhood wine shop Fíon Eile's owners, Paul Gartland and Sinéad McCarthy, have collaborated with some of our most interesting wine importers on a series of tastings for local wine lovers.

This month, they team up with Maggie Domaradzka and Maja Ignaczewska behind the dynamic Polish Wine Fest for a celebration of bubbles from above 50 degrees north of the equator. Maggie and Maja never fail to deliver a fun and fascinating event and, over this 90-minute ticketed session (€38.52), you can taste 15 different Polish sparkling wines - from?traditional-method sparklers?(think Polish-style champagne) to vibrant, low-intervention?Pet-Nats. polishwinefest.com, fioneile.ie

Dundalk Food & Drink Society

Dundalk, Co Louth

Food and drink are excellent levellers, and with members ranging from 18 to 90 years old, this Dundalk-based society of local foodies is doing a fine job of fostering intergenerational friendships.

Founder Sarah Jane Carville describes the society as "a community of passionate individuals who celebrate culinary diversity and are dedicated to exploring new flavours, techniques and cuisines".

Attracting 200 members in their first year, their busy calendar of events includes monthly supper clubs with local chefs, 'Taste the Town' food-and-drink pairings hosted in community hubs like Mo Chara brewpub, and 'Meet the Maker' day-trips to local producers.

A visit to Carlingford Oyster Company run by the wonderful Kian Louet-Feisser and family was a recent highlight, as was the first of the summer's bus trips across the Cooley Peninsula, tasting everything from apple tarts to lobster rolls, to be repeated on July 19. @dundalk_food_and_drink_society

Scorchio HQ, Greenmount Industrial Estate, Harold's Cross, Dublin 12

From the people behind Dublin's Big Grill festival (August 14-17), which gathers live-fire-obsessed cooks and chefs from around the world for one smoking weekend in Herbert Park, Scorchio HQ is their new year-round headquarters for pop-ups, parties and weekly markets, with Me Auld Flower food market running every Sunday this summer.

Pride of place goes to the Scorchio live-fire grill, complemented by a wine bar and rotating guest vendors from the likes of Teddy's, Xi'an Street Food and Home Dogs.

Accessed through the building of a former film studio, the sun-trap yard (with indoor toilets) has been reconfigured as "a space built for chefs, creators and food lovers, offering a place to cook, connect and celebrate".

Check @scorchiohq each week on Instagram for that week's line-up and opening times. scorchiohq.com, @meauldflowerfestival

August 9, The White Hag Brewery, Ballymote, Co Sligo

Hagstravaganza brings a global line-up of breweries from the US, UK, Italy, France and Ireland to Ballymote for a one-day celebration of bold beers and community buzz.

Now in its 11th year, this is more than a festival, says White Hag Brewery founder Bob Coggins: "It's a reunion. Every year we welcome back friends from the brewing community, who travel across the world to join us, alongside a growing local and national crowd of die-hard beer lovers. It's the kind of event where brewers pour pints, punters turn into pals, and everyone leaves with a new favourite beer... and a few new mates."

Various locations in Dublin

To build bridges between cultures through food shared and knowledge exchanged.

Brookfield Farm

Coolbawn, Nenagh, Co Tipperary

Ailbhe Gerrard's regenerative farm produces raw Irish honey, potatoes, rapeseed oil and organic lamb, plus handcrafted candles, beeswax furniture polish and gardener's hand salve. Saturday's family-friendly programme features craft workshops, local Tipperary food and craft stalls, sensory farm walks, agroforestry and dry-stone wall exhibits, specially commissioned artworks and a musical performance from The Company of Trees. brookfield.farm/field-exchange-festival

Besides its action-packed programme of trails, tours and tastings, demos and workshops, dinners and markets, Cork on a Fork has an impressive and varied line-up of free events that include lots of juicy conversations between some of the key movers and shakers in Irish food and drink today. corkcity.ie/en/cork-on-a-fork-fest
